paragraphs.text: Black-and-white (B&W or B/W) images combine black and white in a continuous spectrum, producing a range of shades of grey.

paragraphs.title: Media
paragraphs.text: The history of various visual media began with black and white, and as technology improved, altered to color.  However, there are exceptions to this rule, including black-and-white fine art photography, as well as many film motion pictures and art film(s).

paragraphs.title: Contemporary use
paragraphs.text: Since the late 1960s, few mainstream films have been shot in black-and-white. The reasons are frequently commercial, as it is difficult to sell a film for television broadcasting if the film is not in color. 1961 was the last year in which the majority of Hollywood films were released in black and white.[1]

paragraphs.title: Computing
paragraphs.text: In computing terminology, black-and-white is sometimes used to refer to a binary image consisting solely of pure black pixels and pure white pixels; what would normally be called a black-and-white image, that is, an image containing shades of gray, is referred to in this context as grayscale.[2]
